info.title: Dynatrace Environment API
info.description:
Documentation of the Dynatrace Environment API v2. Resources here generally supersede those in v1. Migration of resources from v1 is in progress. If you miss a resource, consider using the Dynatrace Environment API v1. Refer to the [help page](https://www.dynatrace.com/support/help/shortlink/env-api) to read about use cases and examples.

Notes about compatibility:
* Operations marked as early adopter or preview may be changed in non-compatible ways, although we try to avoid this.
* We may add new enum constants without incrementing the API version; thus, clients need to handle unknown enum constants gracefully.

tags.name: Metrics
tags.description: Read metrics and their data points

tags.name: Monitored entities - Custom tags
tags.description: Manage custom tags of monitored entities

get.summary: List ActiveGates with update jobs | maturity=EARLY_ADOPTER
get.description: The response includes ActiveGates that have both completed (successful and failed) jobs and jobs in progress.

parameters.name: from
parameters.description:
The start of the requested timeframe for update jobs. 

You can use one of the following formats: 
* Timestamp in UTC milliseconds. 
* Human-readable format of `2019-12-21T05:57:01.123+01:00`. If no time zone is specified, UTC is used. You can use a space character instead of the `T`. Seconds and fractions of a second are optional. 
* Relative timeframe, back from now. The format is `now-NU/A`, where `N` is the amount of time, `U` is the unit of time, and `A` is an alignment. The alignment rounds all the smaller values to the nearest zero in the past. For example, `now-1y/w` is one year back, aligned by a week. 
You can also specify relative timeframe without an alignment: `now-NU`. 
Supported time units for the relative timeframe are: 
* `m`: minutes 
* `h`: hours 
* `d`: days 
* `w`: weeks 
* `M`: months 
* `y`: years 

If not set, the relative timeframe of one day is used (`now-1d`). 

Maximum timeframe is 31 days.

parameters.name: to
parameters.description:
The end of the requested timeframe for update jobs. 

You can use one of the following formats: 
* Timestamp in UTC milliseconds. 
* Human-readable format of `2019-12-21T05:57:01.123+01:00`. If no time zone is specified, UTC is used. You can use a space character instead of the `T`. Seconds and fractions of a second are optional. 
* Relative timeframe, back from now. The format is `now-NU/A`, where `N` is the amount of time, `U` is the unit of time, and `A` is an alignment. The alignment rounds all the smaller values to the nearest zero in the past. For example, `now-1y/w` is one year back, aligned by a week. 
You can also specify relative timeframe without an alignment: `now-NU`. 
Supported time units for the relative timeframe are: 
* `m`: minutes 
* `h`: hours 
* `d`: days 
* `w`: weeks 
* `M`: months 
* `y`: years 

If not set, the current timestamp is used.

parameters.name: startVersionCompareType
parameters.description:
Filters the resulting set of update jobs by the specified initial version. 

 Specify the comparison operator here.

parameters.name: startVersion
parameters.description: Filters the resulting set of update-jobs by the initial version (required format `<major>.<minor>.<revision>`).

parameters.name: updateType
parameters.description: Filters the resulting set of update-jobs by the update type.

parameters.name: targetVersionCompareType
parameters.description:
Filters the resulting set of update jobs by the specified target version. 

 Specify the comparison operator here.

parameters.name: targetVersion
parameters.description: Filters the resulting set of update-jobs by the target version (required format `<major>.<minor>.<revision>`).

get.summary: Lists update jobs for the specified ActiveGate | maturity=EARLY_ADOPTER
get.description: The job can update the ActiveGate to the specified version or the latest available one.

parameters.name: agId
parameters.description: The ID of the required ActiveGate.

parameters.name: from
parameters.description:
The start of the requested timeframe for update jobs. 

You can use one of the following formats: 
* Timestamp in UTC milliseconds. 
* Human-readable format of `2019-12-21T05:57:01.123+01:00`. If no time zone is specified, UTC is used. You can use a space character instead of the `T`. Seconds and fractions of a second are optional. 
* Relative timeframe, back from now. The format is `now-NU/A`, where `N` is the amount of time, `U` is the unit of time, and `A` is an alignment. The alignment rounds all the smaller values to the nearest zero in the past. For example, `now-1y/w` is one year back, aligned by a week. 
You can also specify relative timeframe without an alignment: `now-NU`. 
Supported time units for the relative timeframe are: 
* `m`: minutes 
* `h`: hours 
* `d`: days 
* `w`: weeks 
* `M`: months 
* `y`: years 

If not set, the relative timeframe of one week is used (`now-1w`). 

Maximum timeframe is 31 days.

parameters.name: to
parameters.description:
The end of the requested timeframe for update jobs. 

You can use one of the following formats: 
* Timestamp in UTC milliseconds. 
* Human-readable format of `2019-12-21T05:57:01.123+01:00`. If no time zone is specified, UTC is used. You can use a space character instead of the `T`. Seconds and fractions of a second are optional. 
* Relative timeframe, back from now. The format is `now-NU/A`, where `N` is the amount of time, `U` is the unit of time, and `A` is an alignment. The alignment rounds all the smaller values to the nearest zero in the past. For example, `now-1y/w` is one year back, aligned by a week. 
You can also specify relative timeframe without an alignment: `now-NU`. 
Supported time units for the relative timeframe are: 
* `m`: minutes 
* `h`: hours 
* `d`: days 
* `w`: weeks 
* `M`: months 
* `y`: years 

If not set, the current timestamp is used.

parameters.name: startVersionCompareType
parameters.description:
Filters the resulting set of update jobs by the specified initial version. 

 Specify the comparison operator here.

parameters.name: startVersion
parameters.description: Filters the resulting set of update-jobs by the initial version (required format `<major>.<minor>.<revision>`).

parameters.name: updateType
parameters.description: Filters the resulting set of update-jobs by the update type.

parameters.name: targetVersionCompareType
parameters.description:
Filters the resulting set of update jobs by the specified target version. 

 Specify the comparison operator here.

parameters.name: targetVersion
parameters.description: Filters the resulting set of update-jobs by the target version (required format `<major>.<minor>.<revision>`).

404.description: Not found. See response body for details.

post.summary: Creates a new update job for the specified ActiveGate | maturity=EARLY_ADOPTER

parameters.name: agId
parameters.description: The ID of the required ActiveGate.

requestBody.description: JSON body of the request, containing update-job parameters.

201.description: Success. The update-job have been created.

get.summary: Gets the parameters of the specified update job | maturity=EARLY_ADOPTER

parameters.name: agId
parameters.description: The ID of the required ActiveGate.

parameters.name: jobId
parameters.description: A unique identifier for a update-job of ActiveGate.

404.description: Not found. See response body for details.

delete.summary: Deletes the specified update job | maturity=EARLY_ADOPTER

parameters.name: agId
parameters.description: The ID of the required ActiveGate.

parameters.name: jobId
parameters.description: A unique identifier for a update-job of ActiveGate.

204.description: Success. The update-job have been deleted. Response doesn't have a body.

404.description: Not found. See response body for details.

post.summary: Validates the payload for the `POST /activeGates/{agId}/updateJobs` request. | maturity=EARLY_ADOPTER

parameters.name: agId
parameters.description: The ID of the required ActiveGate.

requestBody.description: JSON body of the request, containing update-job parameters.

204.description: Validated. The submitted update-job is valid. Response doesn't have a body.

get.summary: Lists all available ActiveGates | maturity=EARLY_ADOPTER
get.description: The response includes all ActiveGates that are currently connected to the environment or have been connected during last 2 hours.

parameters.name: hostname
parameters.description:
Filters the resulting set of ActiveGates by the name of the host it's running on. 

 You can specify a partial name. In that case, the `CONTAINS` operator is used.

parameters.name: osType
parameters.description: Filters the resulting set of ActiveGates by the OS type of the host it's running on.

parameters.name: networkAddress
parameters.description:
Filters the resulting set of ActiveGates by the network address. 

 You can specify a partial address. In that case, the `CONTAINS` operator is used.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: Filters the resulting set of ActiveGates by the ActiveGate type.

parameters.name: networkZone
parameters.description:
Filters the resulting set of ActiveGates by the network zone. 

 You can specify a partial name. In that case, the `CONTAINS` operator is used.

parameters.name: updateStatus
parameters.description: Filters the resulting set of ActiveGates by the auto-update status.

parameters.name: versionCompareType
parameters.description:
Filters the resulting set of ActiveGates by the specified version. 

 Specify the comparison operator here.

parameters.name: version
parameters.description:
Filters the resulting set of ActiveGates by the specified version. 

 Specify the version in `<major>.<minor>.<revision>` format (for example, `1.195.0`) here.

get.summary: Gets the details of the specified ActiveGate | maturity=EARLY_ADOPTER

parameters.name: agId
parameters.description: The ID of the required ActiveGate.

404.description: Not found. See response body for details.

get.summary: Gets the audit log of your Dynatrace environment | maturity=EARLY_ADOPTER
get.description:
You can limit the output by using pagination: 
1. Specify the number of results per page in the **pageSize** query parameter. 
2. Use the cursor from the **nextPageKey** field of the previous response in the **nextPageKey** query parameter to obtain subsequent pages.

parameters.name: nextPageKey
parameters.description:
The cursor for the next page of results. You can find it in the **nextPageKey** field of the previous response. 

The first page is always returned if you don't specify the **nextPageKey** query parameter. 

When the **nextPageKey** is set to obtain subsequent pages, you must omit all other query parameters.

parameters.name: pageSize
parameters.description:
The desired amount of log entries in a single response payload. 

The maximal allowed page size is 5000. 

If not set, 1000 is used.

parameters.name: filter
parameters.description:
Filters the audit log. You can use the following criteria: 
* User: `user("userIdentification")`. The `EQUALS` operator applies. 
* Event type: `eventType("value")`. The `EQUALS` operator applies. 
* Category of a logged operation: `category("value")`. The `EQUALS` operator applies. 
* Entity ID: `entityId("id")`. The `CONTAINS` operator applies. 

For each criterion, you can specify multiple alternatives with comma-separated values. In this case, the OR logic applies. For example, `eventType("CREATE","UPDATE")` means eventType can be "CREATE" or "UPDATE". 

You can specify multiple comma-separated criteria, such as `eventType("CREATE","UPDATE"),category("CONFIG")`. Only results matching **all** criteria are included in response. 

Specify the value of a criterion as a quoted string. The following special characters must be escaped with a tilde (`~`) inside quotes: 
* Tilde `~` 
* Quote `"`

parameters.name: from
parameters.description:
The start of the requested timeframe. 

You can use one of the following formats: 
* Timestamp in UTC milliseconds. 
* Human-readable format of `2019-12-21T05:57:01.123+01:00`. If no time zone is specified, UTC is used. You can use a space character instead of the `T`. Seconds and fractions of a second are optional. 
* Relative timeframe, back from now. The format is `now-NU/A`, where `N` is the amount of time, `U` is the unit of time, and `A` is an alignment. The alignment rounds all the smaller values to the nearest zero in the past. For example, `now-1y/w` is one year back, aligned by a week. 
You can also specify relative timeframe without an alignment: `now-NU`. 
Supported time units for the relative timeframe are: 
* `m`: minutes 
* `h`: hours 
* `d`: days 
* `w`: weeks 
* `M`: months 
* `y`: years 

If not set, the relative timeframe of two weeks is used (`now-2w`).

parameters.name: to
parameters.description:
The end of the requested timeframe. 

You can use one of the following formats: 
* Timestamp in UTC milliseconds. 
* Human-readable format of `2019-12-21T05:57:01.123+01:00`. If no time zone is specified, UTC is used. You can use a space character instead of the `T`. Seconds and fractions of a second are optional. 
* Relative timeframe, back from now. The format is `now-NU/A`, where `N` is the amount of time, `U` is the unit of time, and `A` is an alignment. The alignment rounds all the smaller values to the nearest zero in the past. For example, `now-1y/w` is one year back, aligned by a week. 
You can also specify relative timeframe without an alignment: `now-NU`. 
Supported time units for the relative timeframe are: 
* `m`: minutes 
* `h`: hours 
* `d`: days 
* `w`: weeks 
* `M`: months 
* `y`: years 

If not set, the current timestamp is used.

parameters.name: sort
parameters.description:
The sorting of audit log entries: 
* `timestamp`: Oldest first. 
* `-timestamp`: Newest first. 

If not set, the newest first sorting is applied.

get.summary: Gets the specified entry of the audit log | maturity=EARLY_ADOPTER

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The ID of the required log entry.

get.summary: Gets a list of properties for all entity types | maturity=EARLY_ADOPTER
get.description:
You can limit the output by using pagination: 
1. Specify the number of results per page in the **pageSize** query parameter. 
2. Use the cursor from the **nextPageKey** field of the previous response in the **nextPageKey** query parameter to obtain subsequent pages.

parameters.name: nextPageKey
parameters.description:
The cursor for the next page of results. You can find it in the **nextPageKey** field of the previous response. 

The first page is always returned if you don't specify the **nextPageKey** query parameter. 

When the **nextPageKey** is set to obtain subsequent pages, you must omit all other query parameters.

parameters.name: pageSize
parameters.description:
The desired amount of entity types in a single response payload. 

The maximal allowed page size is 500. 

If not set, 50 is used.

400.description: Failed. There are no more entity types to export.

post.summary: Creates or updates a custom device | maturity=EARLY_ADOPTER

requestBody.description: The JSON body of the request. Contains parameters of a custom device.

get.summary: Gets a list of properties for the specified entity type | maturity=EARLY_ADOPTER

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: The required entity type.

400.description: Failed. The requested monitored entity type is not exportable or doesn't exist.

get.summary: Gets the information about monitored entities | maturity=EARLY_ADOPTER
get.description:
Lists entities observed within the specified timeframe along with their properties. 

You can limit the output by using pagination: 
1. Specify the number of results per page in the **pageSize** query parameter. 
2. Use the cursor from the **nextPageKey** field of the previous response in the **nextPageKey** query parameter to obtain subsequent pages.

parameters.name: nextPageKey
parameters.description:
The cursor for the next page of results. You can find it in the **nextPageKey** field of the previous response. 

The first page is always returned if you don't specify the **nextPageKey** query parameter. 

When the **nextPageKey** is set to obtain subsequent pages, you must omit all other query parameters.

parameters.name: pageSize
parameters.description:
The desired amount of entities in a single response payload. 

The maximal allowed page size is configurable per environment. 

If not set, 50 is used.

parameters.name: entitySelector
parameters.description:
Defines the scope of the query. Only entities matching the specified criteria are included into response. 

You need to set one of these criteria: 

* Entity type: `type("value")`. 
* Dynatrace entity ID: `entityId("id")`. You can specify several IDs, separated by a comma (`entityId("id-1","id-2")`). 

And you can add one or several of the following criteria: 

* Tag: `tag("value")`. Tags in `[context]key:value`, `key:value`, and `value` formats are detected and parsed automatically. If a value-only tag has a colon (`:`) in it, you must escape the colon with a backslash(`\`). Otherwise, the tag will be parsed as a `key:value` tag. All tag values are case-sensitive. 
* Management zone ID: `mzId("ID")` 
* Management zone name: `mzName("value")`. Management zone names are case-sensitive. 
* Dynatrace entity name: `entityName("value")`. You can specify several entity names, separated by a comma (`entityName("name-1","name-2")`). Entity names are case-sensitive. 
* Health state (HEALTHY,UNHEALTHY): `healthState("HEALTHY")`

Further information can be found [here](https://www.dynatrace.com/support/help/dynatrace-api/environment-api/entity-v2/).
To set several criteria, separate them with a comma (`,`). For example, `type("HOST"),healthState("HEALTHY")`. Only results matching **all** criteria are included in response. 

The length of the string is limited to 10,000 characters. 

The field is **required** when you're querying the first page of results.

parameters.name: from
parameters.description:
The start of the requested timeframe. 

You can use one of the following formats: 
* Timestamp in UTC milliseconds. 
* Human-readable format of `2019-12-21T05:57:01.123+01:00`. If no time zone is specified, UTC is used. You can use a space character instead of the `T`. Seconds and fractions of a second are optional. 
* Relative timeframe, back from now. The format is `now-NU/A`, where `N` is the amount of time, `U` is the unit of time, and `A` is an alignment. The alignment rounds all the smaller values to the nearest zero in the past. For example, `now-1y/w` is one year back, aligned by a week. 
You can also specify relative timeframe without an alignment: `now-NU`. 
Supported time units for the relative timeframe are: 
* `m`: minutes 
* `h`: hours 
* `d`: days 
* `w`: weeks 
* `M`: months 
* `y`: years 

If not set, the relative timeframe of three days is used (`now-3d`).

parameters.name: to
parameters.description:
The end of the requested timeframe. 

You can use one of the following formats: 
* Timestamp in UTC milliseconds. 
* Human-readable format of `2019-12-21T05:57:01.123+01:00`. If no time zone is specified, UTC is used. You can use a space character instead of the `T`. Seconds and fractions of a second are optional. 
* Relative timeframe, back from now. The format is `now-NU/A`, where `N` is the amount of time, `U` is the unit of time, and `A` is an alignment. The alignment rounds all the smaller values to the nearest zero in the past. For example, `now-1y/w` is one year back, aligned by a week. 
You can also specify relative timeframe without an alignment: `now-NU`. 
Supported time units for the relative timeframe are: 
* `m`: minutes 
* `h`: hours 
* `d`: days 
* `w`: weeks 
* `M`: months 
* `y`: years 

If not set, the current timestamp is used.

parameters.name: fields
parameters.description:
Defines the list of entity properties included in the response. The ID and the name of an entity are **always** included to the response. 

To add properties, list them with leading plus `+`. You can specify several properties, separated by a comma (for example `fields=+lastSeenTms,+properties.BITNESS`). 

Use the [GET /entityTypes/{type}](https://www.dynatrace.com/support/help/shortlink/api-entities-v2-get-entity-type) request to fetch the list of properties available for your entity type. Fields from the **properties** object must be specified in the `properties.FIELD` format (for example, `properties.BITNESS`).

get.summary: Gets the properties of the specified monitored entity | maturity=EARLY_ADOPTER

parameters.name: entityId
parameters.description: The ID of the required entity.

parameters.name: from
parameters.description:
The start of the requested timeframe. 

You can use one of the following formats: 
* Timestamp in UTC milliseconds. 
* Human-readable format of `2019-12-21T05:57:01.123+01:00`. If no time zone is specified, UTC is used. You can use a space character instead of the `T`. Seconds and fractions of a second are optional. 
* Relative timeframe, back from now. The format is `now-NU/A`, where `N` is the amount of time, `U` is the unit of time, and `A` is an alignment. The alignment rounds all the smaller values to the nearest zero in the past. For example, `now-1y/w` is one year back, aligned by a week. 
You can also specify relative timeframe without an alignment: `now-NU`. 
Supported time units for the relative timeframe are: 
* `m`: minutes 
* `h`: hours 
* `d`: days 
* `w`: weeks 
* `M`: months 
* `y`: years 

If not set, the relative timeframe of three days is used (`now-3d`).

parameters.name: to
parameters.description:
The end of the requested timeframe. 

You can use one of the following formats: 
* Timestamp in UTC milliseconds. 
* Human-readable format of `2019-12-21T05:57:01.123+01:00`. If no time zone is specified, UTC is used. You can use a space character instead of the `T`. Seconds and fractions of a second are optional. 
* Relative timeframe, back from now. The format is `now-NU/A`, where `N` is the amount of time, `U` is the unit of time, and `A` is an alignment. The alignment rounds all the smaller values to the nearest zero in the past. For example, `now-1y/w` is one year back, aligned by a week. 
You can also specify relative timeframe without an alignment: `now-NU`. 
Supported time units for the relative timeframe are: 
* `m`: minutes 
* `h`: hours 
* `d`: days 
* `w`: weeks 
* `M`: months 
* `y`: years 

If not set, the current timestamp is used.

parameters.name: fields
parameters.description:
Defines the list of entity properties included in the response. The ID and the name of an entity are **always** included to the response. 

To add properties, list them with leading plus `+`. You can specify several properties, separated by a comma (for example `fields=+lastSeenTms,+properties.BITNESS`). 

Use the [GET /entityTypes/{type}](https://www.dynatrace.com/support/help/shortlink/api-entities-v2-get-entity-type) request to fetch the list of properties available for your entity type. Fields from the **properties** object must be specified in the `properties.FIELD` format (for example, `properties.BITNESS`).

get.summary: Lists all available metrics
get.description:
You can narrow down the output by selecting metrics in the **metricSelector** field. 

You can additionally limit the output by using pagination: 

1. Specify the number of results per page in the **pageSize** query parameter. 

2. Then use the cursor from the **nextPageKey** field of the response in the **nextPageKey** query parameter to obtain subsequent pages. All other query parameters must be omitted.

parameters.name: nextPageKey
parameters.description:
The cursor for the next page of results. You can find it in the **nextPageKey** field of the previous response. 

The first page is always returned if you don't specify the **nextPageKey** query parameter. 

When the **nextPageKey** is set to obtain subsequent pages, you must omit all other query parameters.

parameters.name: pageSize
parameters.description:
The desired amount of primary entities in a single response payload. 

The maximal allowed page size is 5000. 

If not set, 100 is used.

 If a value higher than 5000 is used, only 5000 results per page are returned.

parameters.name: metricSelector
parameters.description:
Selects metrics for the query by their keys.

 You can specify multiple metric keys separated by commas (for example, `metrickey1,metrickey2`). To select multiple metrics belonging to the same parent, list the last part of the required metric keys in parentheses, separated by commas, while keeping the common part untouched. For example, to list the `builtin:host.cpu.idle` and `builtin:host.cpu.user` metric, write: `builtin:host.cpu.(idle,user)`. 

You can select a full set of related metrics by using a trailing asterisk (`*`) wildcard. For example, `builtin:host.*` selects all host-based metrics and `builtin:*` selects all Dynatrace-provided metrics. 

You can set additional transformation operators, separated by a colon (`:`). See the [Metrics API - selector transformations help page](https://www.dynatrace.com/support/help/shortlink/api-metrics-v2-selector) for additional information on available result transformations.

 The length of the string is limited to 1,000 characters.

 To find metrics based on a search term, rather than metricID, use the **text** query parameter instead of this one.

parameters.name: text
parameters.description: Metric registry search term. Only show metrics that contain the term in their ID, display name, or description. Use the `metricSelector` parameter instead of this one to select a complete metric hierarchy instead of doing a text-based search.

parameters.name: fields
parameters.description:
Defines the list of metric properties included in the response. 

`metricId` is **always** included in the result. The following additional properties are available: 

* `displayName`: The name of the metric in the user interface. Enabled by default. 
* `description`: A short description of the metric. Enabled by default. 
* `unit`: The unit of the metric. Enabled by default. 
+ `dduBillable`:  An indicator whether the usage of metric consumes [Davis data units](https://www.dynatrace.com/support/help/shortlink/davis-data-units). 
* `aggregationTypes`: The list of allowed aggregations for the metric. Note that it may be different after a [transformation](https://www.dynatrace.com/support/help/shortlink/api-metrics-v2-selector) is applied. 
* `defaultAggregation`: The default aggregation of the metric. It is used when no aggregation is specified or the `:auto` transformation is set. 
* `dimensionDefinitions`: The fine metric division (for example, process group and process ID for some process-related metric). 
* `transformations`: A list of [transformations](https://www.dynatrace.com/support/help/shortlink/api-metrics-v2-selector) that can be applied to the metric.
* `entityType`: A list of entity types supported by the metric.

To add properties, list them with leading plus `+`. To exclude default properties, list them with leading minus `-`. 

To specify several properties, join them with a comma (for example `fields=+aggregationTypes,-description`).

If you specify just one property, the response contains the metric key and the specified property.To return metric keys only, specify `metricId` here.

400.description: Syntax or validation error. **metricSelector** or **fields** have syntactic or semantic errors.

404.description: Not found. The requested resource is not found or the query is incorrect.

406.description: Not acceptable. The requested media type is not supported. Check the **Accept** header of your request.

x-token-scopes: `DataExport` (Access problem and event feed, metrics, and topology)

get.summary: Gets the descriptor of the specified metric

parameters.name: metricId
parameters.description:
The key of the required metric. 

You can set additional transformation operators, separated by a colon (`:`). See the [Metrics API - selector transformations help page](https://www.dynatrace.com/support/help/shortlink/api-metrics-v2-selector) for additional information on available result transformations.

 The length of the string is limited to 1,000 characters.

404.description: Not found. The requested resource is not found or the query is incorrect.

406.description: Not acceptable. The requested media type is not supported. Check the **Accept** header of your request.

x-token-scopes: `DataExport` (Access problem and event feed, metrics, and topology)

get.summary: Gets data points of the specified metrics
get.description:
The following limits apply: 
* The amount of aggregated data points in the response is limited to 1,000 
* The amount of series in the response is limited to 1,000 
   * The amount of data points per series is limited to 10,080 
   * The overall amount of data points is limited to 100,000

parameters.name: nextPageKey
parameters.description:
The cursor for the next page of results. You can find it in the **nextPageKey** field of the previous response. 

The first page is always returned if you don't specify the **nextPageKey** query parameter. 

When the **nextPageKey** is set to obtain subsequent pages, you must omit all other query parameters.

parameters.name: pageSize
parameters.description:
The desired amount of primary entities in a single response payload. 

The maximal allowed page size is 5000. 

If not set, 100 is used.

 If a value higher than 5000 is used, only 5000 results per page are returned.

parameters.name: metricSelector
parameters.description:
Selects metrics for the query by their keys. You can select up to 10 metrics for one query.

 You can specify multiple metric keys separated by commas (for example, `metrickey1,metrickey2`). To select multiple metrics belonging to the same parent, list the last part of the required metric keys in parentheses, separated by commas, while keeping the common part untouched. For example, to list the `builtin:host.cpu.idle` and `builtin:host.cpu.user` metric, write: `builtin:host.cpu.(idle,user)`. 

You can set additional transformation operators, separated by a colon (`:`). See the [Metrics API - selector transformations help page](https://www.dynatrace.com/support/help/shortlink/api-metrics-v2-selector) for additional information on available result transformations.

 If the metric key contains the following characters, they must be escaped with a tilde (`~`): 

* Period (`.`) 
* Comma (`,`) 
* Colon (`:`) 
* Opening and closing brackets (`()`) 
* Tilde (`~`) 

For example, to query the metric with the key of **ext:Apache, nginx (Web Servers)** and the dimension of **Index (incl., max ~8)** for the value of `8`, you must specify this selector: `ext:Apache~, nginx ~(Web Servers~):filter(Index ~(incl~.~,max ~~8~),8)`

 The length of the string is limited to 1,000 characters.

parameters.name: resolution
parameters.description:
The desired resolution of data points. 

You can use one of the following options: 
* One aggregated data point of each series. Set `Inf` to use this option. 
* The desired amount of data points. This is the default option. This is a reference number of points, which is not necessarily equal to the number of the returned data points. 
* The desired timespan between data points. This is a reference timespan, which is not necessarily equal to the returned timespan. To use this option, specify the unit of the timespan. 

Valid units for the timespan are: 
* `m`: minutes 
* `h`: hours 
* `d`: days 
* `w`: weeks 
* `M`: months 
* `y`: years 

If not set, the default is 120 **data points**.

parameters.name: from
parameters.description:
The start of the requested timeframe. 

You can use one of the following formats: 
* Timestamp in UTC milliseconds. 
* Human-readable format of `2019-12-21T05:57:01.123+01:00`. If no time zone is specified, UTC is used. You can use a space character instead of the `T`. Seconds and fractions of a second are optional. 
* Relative timeframe, back from now. The format is `now-NU/A`, where `N` is the amount of time, `U` is the unit of time, and `A` is an alignment. The alignment rounds all the smaller values to the nearest zero in the past. For example, `now-1y/w` is one year back, aligned by a week. 
You can also specify relative timeframe without an alignment: `now-NU`. 
Supported time units for the relative timeframe are: 
* `m`: minutes 
* `h`: hours 
* `d`: days 
* `w`: weeks 
* `M`: months 
* `y`: years 

If not set, the relative timeframe of two weeks is used (`now-2w`).

parameters.name: to
parameters.description:
The end of the requested timeframe. 

You can use one of the following formats: 
* Timestamp in UTC milliseconds. 
* Human-readable format of `2019-12-21T05:57:01.123+01:00`. If no time zone is specified, UTC is used. You can use a space character instead of the `T`. Seconds and fractions of a second are optional. 
* Relative timeframe, back from now. The format is `now-NU/A`, where `N` is the amount of time, `U` is the unit of time, and `A` is an alignment. The alignment rounds all the smaller values to the nearest zero in the past. For example, `now-1y/w` is one year back, aligned by a week. 
You can also specify relative timeframe without an alignment: `now-NU`. 
Supported time units for the relative timeframe are: 
* `m`: minutes 
* `h`: hours 
* `d`: days 
* `w`: weeks 
* `M`: months 
* `y`: years 

If not set, the current timestamp is used.

parameters.name: entitySelector
parameters.description:
Specifies the entity scope of the query. Only data points delivered by matched entities are included in response. 

You need to set one of these criteria: 

* Entity type: `type("value")`. 
* Dynatrace entity ID: `entityId("id")`. You can specify several IDs, separated by a comma (`entityId("id-1","id-2")`). 

And you can add one or several of the following criteria: 

* Tag: `tag("value")`. Tags in `[context]key:value`, `key:value`, and `value` formats are detected and parsed automatically. If a value-only tag has a colon (`:`) in it, you must escape the colon with a backslash(`\`). Otherwise, the tag will be parsed as a `key:value` tag. All tag values are case-sensitive. 
* Management zone ID: `mzId("ID")` 
* Management zone name: `mzName("value")`. Management zone names are case-sensitive. 
* Dynatrace entity name: `entityName("value")`. You can specify several entity names, separated by a comma (`entityName("name-1","name-2")`). Entity names are case-sensitive. 
* Health state (HEALTHY,UNHEALTHY): `healthState("HEALTHY")`

Further information can be found [here](https://www.dynatrace.com/support/help/dynatrace-api/environment-api/entity-v2/).
To set several criteria, separate them with a comma (`,`). For example, `type("HOST"),healthState("HEALTHY")`. Only results matching **all** criteria are included in response. 

The length of the string is limited to 10,000 characters. 

Use the [`GET /metrics/{metricId}`](https://www.dynatrace.com/support/help/shortlink/api-metrics-v2-get-descriptor) call to fetch the list of possible entity types for your metric. 

To set a universal scope matching all entities, omit this parameter.

400.description: Syntax or validation error. From and to parameters, scope or resolution are incorrect individually or in their combined meaning.

403.description: Failed. The request is valid but the response is too big to process. Split your query into several queries with limited scopes.

404.description: Not found. The requested resource is not found or the query is incorrect.

406.description: Not acceptable. The requested media type is not supported. Check the **Accept** header of your request.

x-token-scopes: `DataExport` (Access problem and event feed, metrics, and topology)

get.summary: Gets parameters of the specified network zone | maturity=EARLY_ADOPTER

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The ID of the required network zone.

put.summary: Updates an existing network zone or creates a new one | maturity=EARLY_ADOPTER
put.description:
If the network zone with the specified ID does not exist, a new network zone is created. 

 The ID is not case sensitive. Dynatrace stores the ID in lowercase.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description:
The ID of the network zone to be updated. 

 If you set the ID in the body as well, it must match this ID. 

 The ID is not case sensitive. Dynatrace stores the ID in lowercase.

requestBody.description: The JSON body of the request. Contains parameters of the network zone.

201.description: Success. The new network zone has been created. The response body contains the ID of the new network zone.

204.description: Success. The network zone has been updated. Response doesn't have a body.

delete.summary: Deletes the specified network zone | maturity=EARLY_ADOPTER
delete.description:
You can only delete an empty network zone (a zone that no ActiveGate or OneAgent is using). 

 If the network zone is used as an alternative zone for any OneAgent, it will be automatically removed from the list of possible alternatives.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The ID of the network zone to be deleted.

204.description: Deleted. Response doesn't have a body.

400.description: Failed. See error message in the response body for details.

requestBody.description: The JSON body of the request. Contains global configuration of network zones.

204.description: Success. The global network zones configuration has been updated. Response doesn't have a body.

get.summary: Gets a list of custom tags applied to the specified entities | maturity=EARLY_ADOPTER
get.description: Automatically applied tags and imported tags are not included.

parameters.name: entitySelector
parameters.description:
Specifies the entities where you want to read tags. 

You need to set one of these criteria: 

* Entity type: `type("value")`. 
* Dynatrace entity ID: `entityId("id")`. You can specify several IDs, separated by a comma (`entityId("id-1","id-2")`). 

And you can add one or several of the following criteria: 

* Tag: `tag("value")`. Tags in `[context]key:value`, `key:value`, and `value` formats are detected and parsed automatically. If a value-only tag has a colon (`:`) in it, you must escape the colon with a backslash(`\`). Otherwise, the tag will be parsed as a `key:value` tag. All tag values are case-sensitive. 
* Management zone ID: `mzId("ID")` 
* Management zone name: `mzName("value")`. Management zone names are case-sensitive. 
* Dynatrace entity name: `entityName("value")`. You can specify several entity names, separated by a comma (`entityName("name-1","name-2")`). Entity names are case-sensitive. 
* Health state (HEALTHY,UNHEALTHY): `healthState("HEALTHY")`

Further information can be found [here](https://www.dynatrace.com/support/help/dynatrace-api/environment-api/entity-v2/).
To set several criteria, separate them with a comma (`,`). For example, `type("HOST"),healthState("HEALTHY")`. Only results matching **all** criteria are included in response. 

The length of the string is limited to 10,000 characters.

post.summary: Adds custom tags to the specified entities | maturity=EARLY_ADOPTER

parameters.name: entitySelector
parameters.description:
Specifies the entities where you want to update tags. 

You need to set one of these criteria: 

* Entity type: `type("value")`. 
* Dynatrace entity ID: `entityId("id")`. You can specify several IDs, separated by a comma (`entityId("id-1","id-2")`). 

And you can add one or several of the following criteria: 

* Tag: `tag("value")`. Tags in `[context]key:value`, `key:value`, and `value` formats are detected and parsed automatically. If a value-only tag has a colon (`:`) in it, you must escape the colon with a backslash(`\`). Otherwise, the tag will be parsed as a `key:value` tag. All tag values are case-sensitive. 
* Management zone ID: `mzId("ID")` 
* Management zone name: `mzName("value")`. Management zone names are case-sensitive. 
* Dynatrace entity name: `entityName("value")`. You can specify several entity names, separated by a comma (`entityName("name-1","name-2")`). Entity names are case-sensitive. 
* Health state (HEALTHY,UNHEALTHY): `healthState("HEALTHY")`

Further information can be found [here](https://www.dynatrace.com/support/help/dynatrace-api/environment-api/entity-v2/).
To set several criteria, separate them with a comma (`,`). For example, `type("HOST"),healthState("HEALTHY")`. Only results matching **all** criteria are included in response. 

The length of the string is limited to 10,000 characters.

requestBody.description: The JSON body of the request. Contains tags to be added to the matching entities.

delete.summary: Deletes the specified tag from the specified entities | maturity=EARLY_ADOPTER

parameters.name: tag
parameters.description: The tag to be deleted.

parameters.name: entitySelector
parameters.description:
Specifies the entities where you want to delete tags. 

You need to set one of these criteria: 

* Entity type: `type("value")`. 
* Dynatrace entity ID: `entityId("id")`. You can specify several IDs, separated by a comma (`entityId("id-1","id-2")`). 

And you can add one or several of the following criteria: 

* Tag: `tag("value")`. Tags in `[context]key:value`, `key:value`, and `value` formats are detected and parsed automatically. If a value-only tag has a colon (`:`) in it, you must escape the colon with a backslash(`\`). Otherwise, the tag will be parsed as a `key:value` tag. All tag values are case-sensitive. 
* Management zone ID: `mzId("ID")` 
* Management zone name: `mzName("value")`. Management zone names are case-sensitive. 
* Dynatrace entity name: `entityName("value")`. You can specify several entity names, separated by a comma (`entityName("name-1","name-2")`). Entity names are case-sensitive. 
* Health state (HEALTHY,UNHEALTHY): `healthState("HEALTHY")`

Further information can be found [here](https://www.dynatrace.com/support/help/dynatrace-api/environment-api/entity-v2/).
To set several criteria, separate them with a comma (`,`). For example, `type("HOST"),healthState("HEALTHY")`. Only results matching **all** criteria are included in response. 

The length of the string is limited to 10,000 characters.

jobId.description: The ID of the update job.

jobState.description: The status of the update job.

updateMethod.description: The method of updating the ActiveGate or its component.

cancelable.description: The job can (`true`) or can't (`false`) be cancelled at the moment.

startVersion.description: The initial version of the ActiveGate.

targetVersion.description:
The target version of the update. 

Specify the version in the `<major>.<minor>.<revision>.<timestamp>` format. 

To update to the latest available version, use the `latest` value.

timestamp.description:
The timestamp of the update job completion. 

 The `null` value means the job is still running.

environments.description: A list of environments (specified by IDs) the ActiveGate can connect to.

duration.description: The duration of the update, in milliseconds.

UpdateJob.description: Configuration of the ActiveGate update job.

updateJobs.description: A list of update jobs of the ActiveGate.

UpdateJobList.description: A list of update jobs of the ActiveGate.

allUpdateJobs.description: A list of ActiveGates with update jobs.

UpdateJobsAll.description: A list of ActiveGates with update jobs.

networkAddresses.description: A list of network addresses of the ActiveGate.

osType.description: The OS type that the ActiveGate is running on.

autoUpdateStatus.description: The current status of auto-updates of the ActiveGate.

offlineSince.description:
The timestamp since when the ActiveGate is offline. 

 The `null` value means the ActiveGate is online.

version.description: The current version of the ActiveGate in the `<major>.<minor>.<revision>.<timestamp>` format.

hostname.description: The name of the host the ActiveGate is running on.

mainEnvironment.description: The ID of the main environment for a multi-environment ActiveGate.

environments.description: A list of environments (specified by IDs) the ActiveGate can connect to.

networkZone.description: The network zone of the ActiveGate.

additionalProperties.description: A list of relationships where the entity occupies the FROM position.

fromRelationships.description: A list of relationships where the entity occupies the FROM position.

additionalProperties.description: A list of relationships where the entity occupies the TO position.

toRelationships.description: A list of relationships where the entity occupies the TO position.

lastSeenTms.description: The timestamp at which the entity was last seen, in UTC milliseconds.

firstSeenTms.description: The timestamp at which the entity was first seen, in UTC milliseconds.

managementZones.description: A list of management zones to which the entity belongs.

tags.description: A list of tags assigned to the entity.

additionalProperties.description: A list of additional properties of the entity.

properties.description: A list of additional properties of the entity.

displayName.description: The name of the entity, displayed in the UI.

Entity.description: The properties of a monitored entity.

EntityId.description: A short representation of a monitored entity.

stringRepresentation.description: The string representation of the tag.

value.description:
The value of the tag. 

 Not applicable to custom tags.

key.description:
The key of the tag. 

 Custom tags have the tag value here.

context.description:
The origin of the tag, such as AWS or Cloud Foundry. 

 Custom tags use the `CONTEXTLESS` value.

METag.description: The tag of a monitored entity.

name.description: The name of the management zone.

id.description: The ID of the management zone.

ManagementZone.description: A short representation of a management zone.

totalCount.description: The total number of entries in the result.

pageSize.description: The number of entries per page.

nextPageKey.description:
The cursor for the next page of results. Has the value of `null` on the last page. 

Use it in the **nextPageKey** query parameter to obtain subsequent pages of the result.

auditLogs.description: A list of audit log entries ordered by the creation timestamp.

AuditLog.description: The audit log of your environment.

logId.description: The ID of the log entry.

eventType.description: The type of the recorded operation.

category.description: The category of the recorded operation.

entityId.description:
The ID of an entity from the **category**. 

 For example, it can be config ID for the `CONFIG` category or token ID for the `TOKEN` category.

environmentId.description: The ID of the Dynatrace environment where the recorded operation occurred.

user.description: The ID of the user who performed the recorded operation.

userType.description: The type of the authentication of the **user**.

userOrigin.description: The origin and the IP address of the **user**.

timestamp.description: The timestamp of the record creation, in UTC milliseconds.

success.description: The recorded operation is successful (`true`) or failed (`false`).

patch.description:
The patch of the recorded operation as the JSON representation. 

 The format is an enhanced RFC 6902. The patch also carries the previous value in the **oldValue** field.

AuditLogEntry.description: An entry of the audit log.

fromRelationships.description: A list of possible relationships where the monitored entity type occupies the FROM position

toRelationships.description: A list of possible relationships where the monitored entity type occupies the TO position.

managementZones.description: The placeholder for the list of management zones of an actual entity.

tags.description: The placeholder for the list of tags of an actual entity.

properties.description: A list of additional properties of the monitored entity type.

type.description: The type of the monitored entity.

EntityType.description: A list of properties of the monitored entity type.

totalCount.description: The total number of entries in the result.

pageSize.description: The number of entries per page.

nextPageKey.description:
The cursor for the next page of results. Has the value of `null` on the last page. 

Use it in the **nextPageKey** query parameter to obtain subsequent pages of the result.

types.description: The list of meta information for all available entity-types

EntityTypeList.description: A list of properties of all available entity types.

EntityTypePropertyDto.description: The property of a monitored entity.

fromTypes.description: A list of monitored entity types that can occupy the FROM position.

FromPosition.description: The FROM position of a relationship.

toTypes.description: A list of monitored entity types that can occupy the TO position.

ToPosition.description: The TO position of a relationship.

entityId.description: The Dynatrace entity ID of the custom device.

groupId.description: The Dynatrace entity ID of the custom device group.

CustomDeviceCreationResult.description: The short representation of a newly created custom device.

customDeviceId.description:
The internal ID of the custom device. 

 If you use the ID of an existing device, the respective parameters will be updated.

displayName.description: The name of the custom device to be displayed in the user interface.

group.description:
User defined group ID of entity. 

The group ID helps to keep a consistent picture of device-group relations. One of many cases where a proper group is important is service detection: you can define which custom devices should lead to the same service by defining the same group ID for them. 

If you set a group ID, it will be hashed into the Dynatrace entity ID of the custom device. In that case the custom device can only be part of one custom device group. 

If you don't set the group ID, Dynatrace will create it based on the ID or type of the custom device. Also, the group will not be hashed into the device ID which means the device may switch groups.

ipAddresses.description:
The list of IP addresses that belong to the custom device. 

These addresses are used to automatically discover the horizontal communication relationship between this component and all other observed components within Smartscape. Once a connection is discovered, it is automatically mapped and shown within Smartscape. 

If you send a value (including an empty value), the existing values will be overwritten. 

If you send `null` or omit this field, the existing values will be kept.

listenPorts.description:
The list of ports the custom devices listens to. 

These ports are used to discover the horizontal communication relationship between this component and all other observed components within Smartscape. 

Once a connection is discovered, it is automatically mapped and shown within Smartscape. 

If ports are specified, you should also add at least one IP address or a DNS name for the custom device. 

If you send a value, the existing values will be overwritten. 

If you send `null`, or an empty value, or omit this field, the existing values will be kept.

type.description:
The technology type definition of the custom device. 

It must be the same technology type of the metric you're reporting. 

If you send a value (including an empty value), the existing value will be overwritten. 

If you send `null` or omit this field, the existing value will be kept.

faviconUrl.description: The icon to be displayed for your custom component within Smartscape. Provide the full URL of the icon file.

configUrl.description: The URL of a configuration web page for the custom device, such as a login page for a firewall or router.

additionalProperties.description: The list of key-value pair properties that will be shown beneath the infographics of your custom device.

properties.description: The list of key-value pair properties that will be shown beneath the infographics of your custom device.

dnsNames.description:
The list of DNS names related to the custom device. 

These names are used to automatically discover the horizontal communication relationship between this component and all other observed components within Smartscape. Once a connection is discovered, it is automatically mapped and shown within Smartscape. 

If you send a value, the existing values will be overwritten. 

If you send `null` or an empty value; or omit this field, the existing values will be kept.

totalCount.description: The total number of entries in the result.

pageSize.description: The number of entries per page.

nextPageKey.description:
The cursor for the next page of results. Has the value of `null` on the last page. 

Use it in the **nextPageKey** query parameter to obtain subsequent pages of the result.

EntitiesList.description: A list of monitored entities along with their properties.

parameter.description:
The percentile to be delivered. Valid values are between `0` and `100`. 

Applicable only to the `percentile` aggregation type.

MetricDefaultAggregation.description: The default aggregation of a metric.

metricId.description:
The fully qualified key of the metric. 

If a transformation has been used it is reflected in the metric key.

dduBillable.description: If `true` the usage of metric consumes [Davis data units](https://www.dynatrace.com/support/help/shortlink/davis-data-units).

entityType.description: List of admissible primary entity types for this metric. Can be used for the `type` predicate in the `entitySelector`.

aggregationTypes.description: The list of allowed aggregations for this metric.

dimensionDefinitions.description: The fine metric division (for example, process group and process ID for some process-related metric).

description.description: A short description of the metric.

transformations.description: Transform operators that could be appended to the current transformation list. Must be enabled with the "fields" parameter on `/metrics` and is always present on `/metrics/{metricId}`.

displayName.description: The name of the metric in the user interface.

example.description: Percentage of user-space CPU time currently utilized, per host.

nextPageKey.description:
The cursor for the next page of results. Has the value of `null` on the last page. 

Use it in the **nextPageKey** query parameter to obtain subsequent pages of the result.

totalCount.description: The estimated number of metrics in the result.

metrics.description: A list of metric along with their descriptors

MetricDescriptorCollection.description: A list of metrics along with their descriptors.

metrics.description: Percentage of CPU time not being utilized, per host.
Percentage of CPU utilized in user space, per host.

index.description:
The unique 0-based index of the dimension. 

 Appending transformations such as :names or :parents may change the indexes of dimensions. `null` is used for the dimensions of a metric with flexible dimensions, which can be referenced with their dimension key, but do not have an intrinsic order that could be used for the index.

key.description:
The key of the dimension. 

 It must be unique within the metric.

nextPageKey.description:
The cursor for the next page of results. Has the value of `null` on the last page. 

Use it in the **nextPageKey** query parameter to obtain subsequent pages of the result.

totalCount.description:
The total number of primary entities in the result. 

Has the `0` value if none of the requested metrics is suitable for pagination.

result.description: A list of metrics and their data points.

MetricData.description: A list of metrics and their data points.

timestamps.description:
A list of timestamps of data points. 

The value of data point for each time from this array is located in **values** array at the same index.

dimensions.description:
The ordered list of dimensions to which the data point list belongs. 

 Each metric can have a certain number of dimensions. Dimensions exceeding this number are aggregated into one, which is shown as `null` here.

values.description:
A list of values of data points. 

The timestamp of data point for each value from this array is located in **timestamps** array at the same index.

MetricSeries.description:
Data points per dimension of a metric. 

The data is represented by two arrays of the same length: **timestamps** and **values**. Entries of the same index from both arrays form a timestamped data point.

metricId.description:
The key of the metric. 

If any transformation is applied, it is included here.

alternativeZones.description: A list of alternative network zones.

numOfOneAgentsUsing.description: The number of OneAgents that are using ActiveGates in the network zone.

numOfConfiguredOneAgents.description: The number of OneAgents that are configured to use the network zone as primary.

numOfOneAgentsFromOtherZones.description:
The number of OneAgents from other network zones that are using ActiveGates in the network zone. 

 This is a fraction of**numOfOneAgentsUsing**. 

One possible reason for switching to another zone is that a firewall is preventing a OneAgent from connecting to any ActiveGate in the preferred network zone.

numOfConfiguredActiveGates.description: The number of ActiveGates in the network zone.

description.description: A short description of the network zone

id.description: The ID of the network zone
The ID of the Dynatrace entity.

name.description: The name of the Dynatrace entity.

description.description: A short description of the Dynatrace entity.

EntityShortRepresentation.description: The short representation of a Dynatrace entity.

example.name: Dynatrace entity
example.description: Dynatrace entity for the REST API example

networkZonesEnabled.description: Network zones feature is enabled (`true`) or disabled (`false`).

SyntheticLocationIdsDto.description: A DTO for synthetic Location IDs.

PrivateSyntheticLocation.description: Configuration of a private synthetic location.

nodes.description: A list of synthetic nodes belonging to a location.

entityId.description: The Dynatrace entity ID of the location.

cloudPlatform.description:
The cloud provider where the location is hosted. 

 Only applicable to `PUBLIC` locations.

ips.description:
The list of IP addresses assigned to the location. 

 Only applicable to `PUBLIC` locations.

status.description: Determines whether a location is enabled, disabled or hidden

SyntheticLocationStatusUpdate.description: Configuration for the status of a synthetic location

status.description:
The status of the location.
ENABLED = Location is shown as active in the UI. Monitors can be assigned to the location
DISABLED = Location is shown as disabled in the UI. No monitors can be assigned to the location. Existing monitors will stay assigned and still be executed on the location.
HIDDEN = Location is hidden from the UI. No monitors can be assigned to the location. Location can only be set to HIDDEN if no monitors are assigned to the location.

type.description:
Defines the actual set of fields depending on the value. See one of the following objects: 

* `PUBLIC` -> SyntheticLocationStatusUpdate 
* `PRIVATE` -> SyntheticPrivationLocationUpdate

SyntheticLocationUpdate.description: The synthetic location update. This is a base object, the exact type depends on the value of the `type` field.

SyntheticPrivationLocationUpdate.description: Configuration of a private synthetic location

nodes.description: A list of synthetic nodes belonging to a location.

countryCode.description:
The country code of the location. 

 Use the alpha-2 code of the [ISO 3166-2 standard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ISO_3166_country_codes), (for example, `AT` for Austria or `PL` for Poland).

regionCode.description:
The region code of the location. 

 For the [USA](https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:code:3166:US) or [Canada](https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:code:3166:CA) use ISO 3166-2 state codes (without `US-` or `CA-` prefix), for example, `VA` for Virginia or `OR` for Oregon. 

 For the rest of the world use [FIPS 10-4 codes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_FIPS_region_codes).

latitude.description: The latitude of the location in `DDD.dddd` format.

longitude.description: The longitude of the location in `DDD.dddd` format.

status.description:
The status of the location.
ENABLED = Location is shown as active in the UI. Monitors can be assigned to the location
DISABLED = Location is shown as disabled in the UI. No monitors can be assigned to the location. Existing monitors will stay assigned and still be executed on the location.
HIDDEN = Location is hidden from the UI. No monitors can be assigned to the location. Location can only be set to HIDDEN if no monitors are assigned to the location.

PublicSyntheticLocation.description: Configuration of a public synthetic location.

cloudPlatform.description: The cloud provider where the location is hosted.

ips.description: The list of IP addresses assigned to the location.

browserType.description: The type of the browser the location is using to execute browser monitors.

browserVersion.description: The version of the browser the location is using to execute browser monitors.

entityId.description: The Dynatrace entity ID of the location.

type.description:
Defines the actual set of fields depending on the value. See one of the following objects: 

* `PUBLIC` -> PublicSyntheticLocation 
* `PRIVATE` -> PrivateSyntheticLocation 
* `CLUSTER` -> PrivateSyntheticLocation

countryCode.description:
The country code of the location. 

 Use the alpha-2 code of the [ISO 3166-2 standard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ISO_3166_country_codes), (for example, `AT` for Austria or `PL` for Poland).

regionCode.description:
The region code of the location. 

 For the [USA](https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:code:3166:US) or [Canada](https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:code:3166:CA) use ISO 3166-2 state codes (without `US-` or `CA-` prefix), for example, `VA` for Virginia or `OR` for Oregon. 

 For the rest of the world use [FIPS 10-4 codes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_FIPS_region_codes).

latitude.description: The latitude of the location in `DDD.dddd` format.

longitude.description: The longitude of the location in `DDD.dddd` format.

SyntheticLocation.description:
Configuration of a synthetic location. 

 **countryCode**, **regionCode**, **city** parameters are optional as they can be retrieved based on **latitude** and **longitude** of location.

 The actual set of fields depends on the **type** of the location.

matchedEntitiesCount.description: The number of monitored entities where the tags have been added.

appliedTags.description: A list of added custom tags.

AddedEntityTags.description: A list of custom tags added to monitored entities.

key.description: The key of the custom tag to be added to monitored entities.

AddEntityTag.description: The custom tag to be added to monitored entities.

tags.description: A list of tags to be added to monitored entities.

AddEntityTags.description: A list of tags to be added to monitored entities.

matchedEntitiesCount.description: The number of monitored entities where the tag has been deleted.

totalCount.description: The total number of tags in the response.

Api-Token.description:
Dynatrace API Token

 The token is passed in the **Authorization** header in the following format: `Authorization: Api-Token abcdefjhij1234567890`.
Api-Token.name: Authorization
